title: Kyabram
text:
Kyabram is a large town in north central <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a>, <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. Kyabram is located in the centre of a rich <a href="irrigation%20district">irrigation district</a> in the <a href="Goulburn%20River">Goulburn River Valley</a>, north of <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>. It is the second-largest town in the <a href="Shire%20of%20Campaspe">Shire of Campaspe</a>, situated between the towns of <a href="Echuca">Echuca</a> and <a href="Shepparton">Shepparton</a> and is close to the <a href="Murray%20River">Murray River</a>, Goulburn River, Campaspe River and Waranga Basin. As of the 2016 census the town had a population of 7,331 people and provides services to a district population of around 16,000.
The name of the town is thought to derive from an Aboriginal word Kiambram meaning "Thick Forest".
History.
The <a href="Yorta%20Yorta">Yorta Yorta</a> people are the original inhabitants of the Goulburn valley.
The township started in the 1870s with the first sale of town blocks held in 1876. Kyabram Post Office opened on 23 September 1878. Sheridan Post Office opened on 1 December 1884. On 8 April 1886, in anticipation of the arrival of the railway at what was then Sheridan, Kyabram was renamed Kyabram East and Sheridan was renamed Kyabram. The Kyabram <a href="Mechanics%27%20Institutes">Mechanics' Institute</a> was built in 1891.
<a href="John%20Allan%20%28Australian%20politician%29">John Allan</a>, who lived in Kyabram from 1873, became <a href="Premier%20of%20Victoria">Premier of Victoria</a> in 1924 and Australia's first <a href="National%20Party%20of%20Australia">Country Party</a> premier. Allan was associated with the <a href="Kyabram%20Reform%20Movement">Kyabram Reform Movement</a>, a conservative political organisation formed at the start of the 20th century and led by Benjamin Goddard, a local businessman. The movement's campaign played a significant role in the downfall of the <a href="Alexander%20Peacock">Peacock</a> state government in June 1902 and its sound defeat in the subsequent <a href="1902%20Victorian%20state%20election">October election</a>. The incoming <a href="William%20Irvine%20%28Australian%20politician%29">Irvine</a> government substantially reduced the number of state parliamentarians, a key demand of the movement.
Kyabram was formally proclaimed a town on 4 July 1973.
The Kyabram Magistrates' Court closed on 1 January 1990.
Economy.
The district is dependent on the primary industries of <a href="dairy">dairy</a>ing and fruit <a href="orchard">orchard</a>s. <a href="Henry%20Jones%20IXL">Henry Jones IXL</a>, a subsidiary of <a href="SPC%20Ardmona">SPC Ardmona</a>, operate a plant in the town, manufacturing IXL <a href="Fruit%20preserves">jams</a>. The town provides engineering, financial advisors, solicitors and accounting services to the district as well as cold storage and specialist dairy services. Kyabram also boasts a family owned Camel dairy unique to Australia. <a href="Nestl%C3%A9">Nestlé</a> (Tongala) downsizing, <a href="Southern%20Processing%20Ltd">Southern Processing Ltd</a> and <a href="Fonterra">Fonterra</a> (Stanhope) all have food processing plants nearby.
Medical and aged care services in the town include a 46-bed hospital, a 30-bed home for the aged, infant welfare centre, ambulance station, several doctors, dentists and other health practitioners. A residential drug and alcohol rehab. In education Kyabram has now combined three state schools (<a href="Kyabram%20P-12%20College">Kyabram Secondary College</a>, Dawes Rd (Demolished) and Haslem St Primary Schools) to one P-12 school containing three campuses (Dawes, Haslem and Fisher). Kyabram also has a Catholic primary and secondary school (St Augustine's College), two kindergartens and the Kyabram Community & Learning Centre providing community services and adult learning opportunities for the people of Kyabram and the surrounding region. The local newspaper is called the "Kyabram Free Press", a part of the McPherson media group in the region, with a circulation of roughly 3,300 copies (Victorian Country Press Association 2008).
Surrounding smaller towns include <a href="Merrigum">Merrigum</a> (pop. 490), <a href="Lancaster%2C%20Victoria">Lancaster</a>, <a href="Undera">Undera</a>, Cooma, Wyuna, Kyvalley, <a href="Girgarre%2C%20Victoria">Girgarre</a>, <a href="Stanhope%2C%20Victoria">Stanhope</a> and <a href="Tongala">Tongala</a>.
Attractions include the <a href="Kyabram%20Fauna%20Park">Kyabram Fauna Park</a>, a reserve housing five hundred species of wildlife. There are free-roaming <a href="kangaroo">kangaroo</a>s and <a href="emu">emu</a>s and hides to observe a variety of water birds.
Sport.
Popular sports in Kyabram include <a href="Australian%20rules%20football">Australian rules football</a> and <a href="cricket">cricket</a>. <a href="Jim%20Higgs">Jim Higgs</a> was a spin bowler from Kyabram who played for Australia during the late 1970s. The local football team is known as the Bombers who compete in the <a href="Goulburn%20Valley%20Football%20League">Goulburn Valley Football League</a>. Kyabram has produced a number of <a href="Australian%20Football%20League">AFL</a> recruits such as GWS utility and former Richmond best-and-fairest <a href="Brett%20Deledio">Brett Deledio</a>, former Melbourne & Victorian Captain <a href="Garry%20Lyon">Garry Lyon</a>, Richmond's <a href="Kayne%20Pettifer">Kayne Pettifer</a>, Brisbane's Patrick Wearden, Hawthorn's Cohen Myers, Carlton's Nick Holman, former North Melbourne rookie Brad Mangan, future Essendon prospect Kaleb Williams and Kyabrams first AFLW's player, Julia Crockett-Grills.
Netball and soccer are also popular in Kyabram. 
Golfers play at the course of the Kyabram Valley View Golf and Bowls Club on Curr Road, Mount Scobie, or at the Kyabram Parkland Golf Club, the home of the Victorian Par 3 Amateur Championships, on Racecourse Rd, Kyabram.
Newly appointed president Tim Nelson and his Secretary Billy Ryan welcome all new visitors with correct green fee receipts and golfing attire.
Notable residents.
In 2016, former resident Kristen Hilton was appointed Victoria's Human Rights Commissioner, head of the <a href="Victorian%20Equal%20Opportunity%20and%20Human%20Rights%20Commission">Victorian Equal Opportunity and Human Rights Commission</a>.
Kyabram is referenced by Irish singer-songwriter <a href="Declan%20O%27Rourke">Declan O'Rourke</a> on his debut album "<a href="Since%20Kyabram">Since Kyabram</a>". O'Rourke picked up his first acoustic guitar while living in the town as a teenager.
